awd_titl_txt: Planning Virtual Strategies to Prepare Science and Mathematics Teachers in Mississippi
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national need for skilled secondary science and mathematics teachers in high-need school districts.  To do so, the project seeks to lay the foundation for secondary-education certification programs adapted to the novel demands of pre- and post-COVID teaching/learning environments.  Conceived initially as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the project aims to use technology and virtual approaches to deliver remote learning opportunities for future teachers.  As such, the project will enable Jackson State University to explore the feasibility of a large-scale effort to increase use of evidence-based, distance-learning strategies in teacher education.  Examples of strategies include virtual simulations, digital credentialing, and online social and emotional learning.  The work will be situated in the urban setting of the Mississippi State capital. 

This project at Jackson State University includes partnerships with Hinds Community College and Jackson Public Schools, a high-need school district. The long-term goal of this collaborative effort is plan how to recruit, support, and graduate teachers who will help meet the shortage of science and mathematics teachers at high-need schools often staffed by rotating long- and short-term substitute teachers. The project builds on the conceptual framework of Jackson State’s College of Education and Human Development vision of the “responsive educator” who provides and embodies: 1) a Committed Response; 2) a Knowledgeable Response; 3) a Skillful Response; and 4) a Professional Response. Additionally, the project builds on the current infrastructure of the University’s Physics and Mathematics Education curriculum. The goals of this Capacity Building project are to: 1) develop evidence-based innovative models and strategies for recruiting, preparing, and supporting teachers; 2) create plans for collecting data to determine need, interest, and capacity for increasing STEM teacher development; and 3) establish the infrastructure for preparing a Track 1: Scholarship & Stipend proposal in the future. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Jackson State University through a partnership with Hinds Community College and Jackson Public Schools, a high-need school district, has worked collaboratively to lay the foundation for secondary-education certification programs adapted to the novel demands of pre- and post-COVID teaching/learning environments. In order to conduct needs assessment and interests, the project team collaborated with PGi and 6Connex to organize a virtual platform to deliver a Science & Mathematics Education Summit. The summit related to five of eight activities described in the proposal: 1) Research and create recruitment plan; 2) Create and approve degree maps for biology and chemistry education; 3) Research virtual simulations and STEM service projects in teacher education; 4) Research and create an evidence-based orientation & mentoring program; and 5) Implement the science and mathematics virtual summit.

The all-day virtual gathering of educators (K-12 teachers, school and district administrators, community college and university faculty and staff, and education researchers) was held on Saturday, March 26, 2022.  PGi reported 176 registrants with 106 actual participants. Among the participants the four largest groups of participants were the K-12 educators (41%), followed by university educators (22%), university students (11%), and other professionals associated in the education and STEM fields (11%). Other professionals included officials from the Mississippi Department of Education, education company representatives, directors of federal grant programs, and session presenters. The time participants spent at the summit and the number of content views varied by group roles. University administrators as a group had the highest median time spent in the summit (8.02 hours) and university students with the least (0.60 hours or 20 minutes). K-12 educators had the highest median content views (33.5). PGi also conducted an analysis of content views. The summit generated 3,673 content views on March 26. The top 10 summit content across different types-- live webinar, pre-recorded video, a link, download, or moderated chat?that generated the most unique views. 

Participants were asked to complete a survey at the conclusion of the summit. There was a 44% response rate with 72% being K-12 educators and 15% being session presenters. Overall, the survey respondents reported that they were "highly" or "very high" satisfied with the sessions. When asked to rate how well they thought of how the summit program was organized and delivered, 87% to 100% of survey respondents said that they "agreed" or "strongly agreed" with the survey statements. For example, 96% of respondents reported that, overall, they were satisfied or highly satisfied with the virtual summit. Also, 95% of respondents reported that the summit met its objectives of presenting research/findings from the field based on best practices to assess the needs of pre- and in-service teachers.

The survey also asked participants open-ended questions. Survey respondents' main takeaways aligned with what PGi uncovered as the sessions with the highest number of content views. The motivational speech and vocabulary challenge and "Baking is Science and Math"  were mentioned at least eight times each. Virtual simulations including Mursion, simSchool and applications of virtual reality (VR) to help pre-service teachers were mentioned at least six times. Also, the respondents repeatedly drew attention to sessions that highlight real-world applications such as "Cosmetology is Science" and made learning fun such as "Fun with Pixel Art, Smartboard Games and Technology." Since the majority of survey respondents and the participants were K-12 educators, these sessions predictably drew frequent mentions since they bring fresh perspectives, excitement, and concrete relevance to the everyday lives and needs of pre- and in-service teachers and the students they serve or will serve. An examination of the responses to the question prompt, "Based on your experience (instructional and research), please mention 4-5 teaching and pedagogical strategies that might be helpful for pre- and in-service STEM teachers" yielded varied responses. These responses can be loosely grouped into at least four areas: 1) repetition of key takeaways or sessions that drew the participants? attention, 2) long-observed professional practices that align with Charlotte Danielson's (2007) framework of teaching, 3) classroom management strategies and techniques, and 4) inquiry-based learning and constructivist approaches to learning.

As a result of summit and collaborative efforts within the project, the team has decided to pursue writing a Track 1: Scholarship and Stipend proposal based on a Middle College School of Innovation partnership with Jackson Public Schools and the Mississippi Department of Education. It would serve as a "grow your own" recruitment program for high school scholars who demonstrate a high mathematical aptitude.
